TopicTitle: Rendezvous with asteroid, can't get desired intercept markers

Articles.Content:
So, I've notice an asteroid has somehow been captured into a wide Kerbin orbit in my career game, set on a collision course for Kerbin. I want to send a ship to it to try to redirect it. I'm trying to set up an orbital trajectory to intercept it, but KSP won't show me useful intercept markers. Look at [this image](http://i.imgur.com/Oo3X3s3.png). I want to have it so that I intercept the asteroid on its orbit around my planned orbit's apoapsis, but KSP insists on showing me rather unhelpful intercept points down close to the planet.

How can I force KSP to show me relative position markers at the point where my planned apoapsis intersects the asteroid's orbit?

**Edited <time datetime="2015-06-07T03:39:41Z" title="06/07/2015 03:39  AM" data-short="9 yr">June 7, 2015</time> by Arkalius**

What KSP is telling you with that, is that your apoapsis DOESN'T intersect the asteroid's orbit. Try right-clicking and moving the camera around.

As to how to set up the intercept, the first thing I would do is to bring your orbiting tug into the same plane as the asteroid - set up a maneuver at the ascending or descending node and burn as necessary to bring that to zero. Then you can push your apoapsis out to where the asteroid will be.

Even if I get it perfectly aligned (they are pretty close in that screenshot) I still don't get a useful intercept marker. And usually, perfect intercept isn't necessary, it will often show closest approach as long as you're relatively close, in my experience.

It means that you'll need to wait until the asteroid is at a different point along its orbital path. The node planner/editor only shows you the next 2 closest points of approach, even if those are a long way apart. With a huge difference in orbital period between LKO and a high Ap orbit such as shown in the picture, it should change fairly quickly.

If the asteroid is up in the top of its orbit, and you're in LKO, then it will be down at the bottom by the time you reach the top. Wait until it's close to Kerbin, then plan your burn and remember to play with the "add an orbit" button shown when you right click on a node that's in edit mode.

It's orbit is out past Minmus, and it's not far from it's apoapsis. It's orbital period is over 2 Kerbin weeks. It's going to take it nearly a week to get down to the distance of the Mun. An orbit that goes out a little past the moon should reach apoapsis before the asteroid even gets that close. I've tested this by creating the orbit with hyperedit and time accelerating. What I want to do will work, KSP just refuses to show relative position markers for me at that point in the orbit.

I'm not trying to match its existing orbit, I'm trying to meet it on the way down, which should work fine, but KSP won't help me make this rendezvous. If I wait until it's close to Kerbin, it will hit the planet before I can get to it. Not only that, but it will require significantly more delta-v to keep it from doing so. The higher up I intercept it, the easier time I'll have moving it's periapsis above the surface and atmosphere.

The problem is, I don't know what that optimal intersection is, and the game refuses to tell me.

I mean think about it... look at the picture. How long will it take the asteroid to move in its own orbit the a point near my planned apoapsis? It will be about the same amount of time it will take me to reach that apoapsis. There is a sweet spot somewhere where I get to apoapsis as the asteroid is crossing that point.

What I need is a way to, say, highlight a point on a planned orbit and have the game tell me where a target will be on its own orbit at the same time.

Ahh, right, I see what you mean. I didn't spot "collision course" in your message or picture. I thought it was just in a highly eccentric orbit, not a suborbital impact trajectory (I think I must have stopped reading after "captured into a wide orbit"). I understand now. Yeah, what you're saying is about right from my experience. The planner doesn't really work terribly well for that situation. I suspect it's due at least partly to math errors and needing to hit a very precise 4D (3D + time) position.

What I've found works is to create a 1st node that puts you in the roughly right area, then add a second node to the projected result of the first, and play around with that; that has allowed me to get an intercept in similar circumstances. Basically plan both your initial and mid-course correction burns at the same time. It's fiddly, but possible, and has worked for me. Using that method, it's still extremely sensitive to tiny adjustments, with the correct intercept point only showing for a very narrow range, tiny adjustments either way and it vanishes again. In initial planning don't worry about completely closing the closest approach, just get confirmation that you'll be within about 250km of it, then do the first burn. After the first burn is complete, you can then more easily refine the mid-course correction burn to narrow the approach, and/or plot additional correction burns and final velocity matching burn.

Yeah, when you zoom out far enough, trajectories that intersect the body's surface no longer clip under the body, so you can't tell it's going to impact from that picture.

I guess I can try what you're saying, but I don't even know where to ballpark the apoapsis at this point... are there any mods that help you predict where bodies will be on their orbit in the future? I could at least come up with a good ballpark if I could plan an orbit, check apoapsis time, and see where the asteroid will be in that time, then adjust as needed.

It's going to require a fair bit of delta-v to get to an intercept (about 1500-2000 I reckon). Then I need to have enough delta-v to move the asteroid out of a collision course. I shouldn't need much but since I don't know the mass of the asteroid I don't know how much fuel I'll want.

My ultimate plan is to try to pull it into a more sane orbit and use it for mining and science if I can. Sounds kinda fun.

Try putting your projected Ap from 1st node about half way between Kerbin and the asteroid's current position, with the Ap marker roughly on top of its descending trajectory. Then try your second node about 50-75% up your ascending trajectory. Play around with both the pro/retrograde and radial adjustments on the 2nd node, plus sliding it up and down the ascending trajectory, until you get at least a flicker of intercept markers. It is all a bit tiresome, really, just a combination of trial, error, and zen. Maybe someone else has found a better trick and will share some better tricks for it. Adjustments/corrections are generally really low cost in terms of dV once you're half way to Mun or further out, but remember to get a read of that 2nd node's required dV before doing the first burn, as it's easy to plot a 1000m/s 2nd node and not realise it (navball only shows dV for 1st node), 2nd needs you to exit node-edit mode and then hover over the unselected 2nd node.

As for mods, don't know. MechJeb didn't have anything useful to say when I asked it about asteroids on impact trajectory the last couple of times.

What the markers show you is closest approach to the target in your next full orbit. So one thing you could try is to put a fake second maneuver node at your apoapsis to raise your periapsis far away from the asteroids. You of course won't actually use this fake node, but you should be able to force it to show you the closest approach near your apoapsis because you give it no other close option on your next orbit.

Another possibility is getting into a matching orbit, but retrograde ... it's not going to be the most efficient, but you'll overfly the asteroid at some point pretty far out, and it won't take much of a radial burn to establish something like a 40-50 km periapsis and just reduce the orbit that way.

So I made it work. It turns out you will get intercept markers there but it's extremely finicky and sensitive. I was able to ballpark it well enough to get there and come to a relative stop within 3.6km. The rest of the rendezvous was fairly easy. I set up a maneuver node that brought the periapsis up to a safe level and lined up the node marker with the center of mass and docked it.

I have some fuel left to bring it's apoapsis down a good bit but I'll have to send another craft (will probably send a mining barge) to fix up its orbit even more. This should be fun!
